content.title: Crawford Classification of Thoracoabdominal Aortic Aneurysms
content.summary: Anatomic classification system for thoracoabdominal aortic aneurysms (TAAA) that predicts operative complexity and spinal cord ischemia risk based on the extent of aortic involvement.

definitions.definition: Aneurysm from distal to the left subclavian artery to above the renal arteries (does not involve visceral segment).
Aneurysm from distal to the left subclavian artery to below the renal arteries (entire descending thoracic and abdominal aorta).
Aneurysm from mid-descending thoracic aorta (T6) to below the renal arteries.
Aneurysm from below the diaphragm to below the renal arteries (primarily abdominal but includes suprarenal segment).
Aneurysm from below T6 to above the renal arteries (does not involve infrarenal aorta).

key_concepts.explanation: Risk varies by Crawford type: Type II has highest risk (10-25%) due to extensive coverage of intercostal arteries. Type IV has lowest risk (2-5%). The artery of Adamkiewicz (typically T9-L2) is critical for spinal cord perfusion.
Classification determines: extent of aortic clamping, number of intercostal reimplantations needed, visceral segment management, and spinal cord protection strategies required.

Strategies include: cerebrospinal fluid drainage, distal aortic perfusion (left heart bypass), hypothermia, intercostal artery reimplantation, staged repair, and permissive hypertension postoperatively.
Refinement adding extent of coverage: Type Ia/Ib (subclavian involvement), Type IIa/IIb (infrarenal extent), allowing better prediction of outcomes and planning.

evidence.citation: Coselli et al., Extent II TAAA Outcomes, 2016
evidence.finding: Contemporary series show paraplegia rates of 4-6% for Type II with modern spinal protection protocols

evidence.citation: Safi et al., Staged Repair Approach, 2003
evidence.finding: Staged repair of extensive aneurysms reduces paraplegia risk by allowing spinal cord collateral development

clinical_pearls: Type II TAAA is the most extensive and challenging with highest spinal cord ischemia risk
CSF drainage is used for all extents but is most critical for Type I, II, and III
Type IV is often managed with open or hybrid approaches similar to juxtarenal AAA
Staged repair (proximal then distal) allows collateral development and reduces SCI risk
Postoperative hypotension is the enemy - maintain MAP >80-90 mmHg
learning_objectives: Describe the anatomic boundaries of each Crawford type
Correlate Crawford type with spinal cord ischemia risk
List spinal cord protection strategies for TAAA repair
Explain the rationale for staged repair of extensive TAAA
Identify the role of CSF drainage in TAAA surgery

cross_domain_references.context: Spinal cord blood supply is critical in TAAA surgery
